I provided this email to both fellows to support their effort to build their lesson plan for their upcoming lessons with a group of newcomers. It was written in response to Monica's inquiry. I'm including Monica's original inquiry and my response (suggestions). 

Hi,
I am working on the LP for the newcomer period tomorrow. 
Just want to double check with you that i will teach the verb "to have," and the numbers. I was also thinking of teaching a few vocabulary words (book, pencil, marker). Will that be too much?
I'll send you the lesson plan as soon as i have it.

I responded with the following:

Hi, Monica,

Thanks for your message. I'm copying Eddie and Laura so we are all on the same page with the newcomer instruction. This will facilitate planning between you and Eddie and will help Laura and I know how we can deliberately support that instruction in the general ed classroom.

As we've discussed, please teach chunks of language. Rather than teach "to have" (which rarely appears in written or spoken English) teach "I have"  "He has" "They have" etc. Please also teach the question frame: Do you have a pencil? (Yes, I have a pencil). I recommend beginning with the do/does question construction because it precedes 'what' questions in the acquisition sequence and is a much more frequently heard question in transactional classroom contexts. 

I would also add: "pick up, notebook, coat, and lunch. As we think about language to teach, think about the types of exchanges students have throughout the day. Example, "Please take out your notebooks. Do you have your notebook?" and "We have recess today. Please bring your coats. Do you have your coat?"

Note: Realia (objects) are very powerful at this stage. So, have all of these objects on hand during your lesson so all students can actually hold the object up as they say, "Yes, I have a notebook." Teach each object with the appropriate article "a notebook."

In my opinion, it will be higher impact to focus on this language in the foreground of your lesson. You can incorporate numbers by counting down and holding up signs with numbers written in word form at different points in the lesson. For example, "Pick up your notebook" then count aloud while holding up signs "ten, nine, eight" etcetera.

Remember, slow, steady and systematic instruction is highest impact for newcomers. You should expect to do lots of repetition. Eddie, you should anticipate reviewing and building on tomorrow's lesson with your Friday lesson. 

One last point: be sure to touch on all four modalities: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. 

Please find the social studies lesson attached to this message. I will create the graphic organizer for this as well as the handout for the writing active engagement activity, as promised. However, please note that moving forward you will be responsible for creating any presentations or materials that accompany your lessons starting next week. As always, let me know if you have any questions.

Best wishes!

Thank you for letting me discuss the Field Experience assignment. I hoped I could work through the challenges and felt encouraged by my lead instructor to persevere and succeed by putting the students first. However after the incident before my field observation on September 29th, I am concerned that even though I am doing everything I can to follow Fellows' practices and keep the coaching relationship positive, my success in the program is in the hands of a coach who does not believe in the NYCTF program and does not give me the specific actionable feedback I need to develop. My coach does not have a positive communication style, and is very sensitive to any perceived criticism or disloyalty. I feel I am walking on eggshells around her. There have been numerous incidents, which I have included below, including retaliation when asked by the Fellows to include me in certain meetings. 

On my first day at the school, Rose Abreu was surprised to see me and appeared highly stressed. She then went on to say that my first week in her classroom was ‘the worst week of her professional life’. I am considerate and respectful of her time and other priorities but I feel unwelcome in her classroom and do not sense that she enjoys the coaching relationship.

My coach is unreceptive to my suggestions or ideas, makes it clear that my role as a Fellow is to accept and obey without question. For example, at first, I felt that I was spending a lot of time photocopying alone or sitting on my own in an empty classroom. I was instructed not to read TLAC or do any college coursework during these empty periods as Mrs Abreu said that the Principal would disapprove if he was to look in and see me. Later, when I asked if I could introduce a ’Do Now’ into the lesson, I was told to just follow her lesson plan exactly. (I have since started doing Do Nows, and they have been accepted into the lesson and are now used more frequently.)

Mrs Abreu is sensitive to any perceived disloyalty. On three separate occasions, I've been reprimanded for having conversations about my classroom experience. None of these conversations were critical of her but there were  consequences for me, including having prep time for the classroom observation taken away from me without notice. Here are the details.

On the first occasion on 9/21 she said she had heard from 'someone via one of the Fellows at the school' that I wanted more teaching time. I was questioned in an accusatory way about why I had discussed my classroom experience with someone else. I felt extremely intimidated even though what I said was respectful and appropriate. I had simply said to my peers about a week earlier that I was not getting as much time with students as I had hoped. I had even asked her a week before that when I might begin teaching small groups and although she seemed irritated that I had brought it up, I was assigned teaching time. She seemed angry that I had spoken to someone else and not at all concerned about allaying my concerns about a gradual release of classroom time. 

After that interaction, I  sent a friendly message to my fellow Fellows at MS319 reminding them that we are building our professional relationships and not to say anything that might be misunderstood or taken out of context. Rose found out about that message and reprimanded me again. She said that was a private conversation and I should not have disclosed it to anyone. 
There was a third incident like this a week later. I don’t know if Lizette will remember this, but when she visited my classroom on 9/28, she observed that I should be attending meetings with the intervention specialists and she would mention it to my coach. I asked Lizette to be very diplomatic about giving that feedback. 

The next day, 45 minutes before the observation, Mrs Abreu told me to stop preparing and said I had to follow her to cover a lesson because 'someone, she didn't know who' had told the Fellows that I should be in all her meetings. After a few minutes, when I realized she would not compromise, I said we should run it past Ms Lloyd to get clarification as this was an important day for me. She said 'this is nothing to do with Ms Lloyd, this is coming directly from the Fellows'. Mrs Abreu came into Ms Lloyd's room and claimed that she had told me that she would allow me to continue preparing for my assessment and that I had walked out of the classroom.  Both of these statements are false. I asked three times if I could finish preparing and received an unequivocal ‘no’ every time. It is my belief that by denying me the little time she had allowed me to prepare, she intended to derail my lesson and upset me before my assessment. That day after school, I stopped in at the Fellows office and told Dana everything. I am concerned that the support and feedback I need is being withheld by my coach. 

There is a disconnect between the support she says she is giving me, and the practical support I am actually receiving. The most measurable disconnect is in the time she says she gives me to prepare.

On 9/29, Mrs Abreu told Ms Lloyd that I had two full periods on Wednesday, the day before the assessment to practice and prepare my lesson - from 8-9:34. What actually happened was that I was instructed to make several hundred lesson plan copies - collated, stapled, etc - for a meeting she was attending later. I started making those copies at 7:50 and finished at 9:15. I had less than 20 minutes to prepare .On another occasion, Mrs Abreu made repeated references to a 3-minute video that was part of the lesson that she says I refused to watch. She did tell me about the video on the Friday before the assessment, but on that day, I was assisting her with putting up classroom bulletin boards prior to school inspection, and in any case, they made no sense without the lesson plan, which I did not receive until after school ended on the following Tuesday (two days before my observation). 

 There are too many instances like this to mention, when she claims that she offered me resources that I have refused to use. These are just not true. I have worked hard to meet all of her demands, and am receptive in accepting and integrating her feedback.

I know that she takes a lot of notes but she rarely shares her specific observations with me. On one occasion, she asked me how I felt a class had gone. I said that I had not been able to bring the class together quickly enough and asked what she suggested I do next time. She said, “I’m not going to tell you, I want you to figure it out yourself.” I thought I had been unclear, and said, “In the Skillbuilding Sessions, we give a glow and a grow” and she said, “Just think, what have you seen me do, or what have you seen one of the other Fellows do?” I was genuinely mystified and gave a very general response which she seemed satisfied with but which did not give me any specifics to draw on for the next time I had that problem.  I rarely receive positive feedback. 

I feel excluded from lesson planning.  There is a tendency to hold back information about the lessons, and it is sometimes difficult for me to find out what will be happening so that I can plan and prepare. Mrs Abreu has resisted all of my efforts to plan out the week in advance. 

Additionally, Mrs Abreu has made it clear that she does not believe in the fellows program (smiled and shook her head when I asked if she had been a fellow). She also said on two occasions that she does not believe there are enough jobs in the city for us saying who's going to hire a new teacher in the middle of the year? 

Finally, I would like to say that I am prepared to do whatever it takes to make this placement work. I have tried to make full use of my time at the school, and have found that other members of staff have been very welcoming to me in their classrooms. This is a wonderful school in which to do Field Experience. At the end of last week, Ms Lloyd asked Mrs Abreu to release me for two periods on Wednesday to observe and ultimately co-teach an ESL class at the school. I am putting my heart and soul into this opportunity and enjoy the time I spend teaching students at this school.

Maria Clegg
